habitat_description:
Gymnogyps californianus nests and roosts in cavities in cliffs, crevices in rock outcrops and among boulders, and cavities in large trees (Wilbur, 1978; Kiff et al., 1984; Snyder, 1986; Zeiner et al., 1990; Stoms et al., 1991; Meretsky and Snyder, 1992). The species' foraging habitat consists of grasslands, savannas (Wilbur, 1978; Stoms et al., 1991; Stoms et al., 1992; Meretsky and Snyder, 1992; Walters et al., 2010) and beaches (Snyder and Schmitt, 2002; Walters et al., 2010). Little foraging takes place within chaparral or in dense forest (Walters et al., 2010).

Condors may travel as far as 180 km from nest site to foraging habitat (Meretsky and Snyder, 1992).

Elevations at which the species has been documented range from sea level (Snyder and Schmitt, 2002) to 2800 m (Hunt et al., 2006).
